revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-26 12:31:25.000000000', 'message': "Track fake stack updates for standalone/UC deploy

Puppet may rely on stack_action != CREATE, so we have to track
it virtually updated for tripleo undercloud/standalone
deployments. For such deployments, the heat stack
update is a fake (virtual), as we never update
but always create a new ephemeral heat stack.

When the deployment is finished w/o errors, create the mark
file that is used to indicate to puppet the stack_action has
been changed from CREATE to UPDATE. The indication is done
via a drop-in t-h-t env file file containing the
'StackAction: UPDATE' override.

When the deployment fails, remove the mark file as we're
not going to track updates for the failed stacks and consider
the next deployment command will CREATE a new stack instead.

For the --output-only mode, warn users to manage the mark
file creation manually, after the manual deployment is
done with direct ansible-playbook invocations.

Closes-bug: #1778505

Change-Id: I55dc83acb2ed5ee07b4cf57e25135e6201589ac4
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2018-06-28 08:53:10.000000000', 'message': "Track fake stack updates for standalone/UC deploy

Puppet relies on stack_action UPDATE for some cases.
Track the ephemeral heat stacks fake state for tripleo
undercloud/standalone deployments to match the puppet
expectations. For such deployments, the heat stack
state is a fake (virtual), as we never
update but always create a new ephemeral heat stack.

When the deployment is finished w/o errors, create the mark
file (unique to the stack name) that is used to indicate to
puppet the stack_action has been changed from CREATE to
UPDATE. The indication is done via a drop-in file with
top level override containing either 'StackAction: CREATE'
or 'UPDATE'. The drop-in is created in the working/templates
directory and named <Stack_name>-stack-vstate-dropin.yaml.

When the deployment fails, remove the mark file, so
the serial re-deployments will be considered as creating
a stack. The --force-stack-update flag keeps the mark file
instead, so the serial re-deployment will be
considered (virtually) updating the heat stack.

For the --output-only mode, only warn users to control
the stack virtual state manually. The state is considered
CREATE, unless there is --force-stack-update specified.

Closes-bug: #1778505

Change-Id: I55dc83acb2ed5ee07b4cf57e25135e6201589ac4
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2018-06-28 12:03:17.000000000', 'message': "Track fake stack updates for standalone/UC deploy

Track the ephemeral heat stacks fake state for tripleo
undercloud/standalone deployments to match the puppet

or 'UPDATE'. The drop-in is created in the working/templates
directory and named <Stack_name>-stack-vstate-dropin.yaml.

When the deployment fails, remove the mark file, so
the serial re-deployments will be considered as creating
a stack. The --force-stack-update flag keeps the mark file
instead, so the serial re-deployment will be
considered (virtually) updating the heat stack.

For the --output-only mode, only warn users to control
the stack virtual state manually. The state is considered
CREATE, unless there is --force-stack-update specified.

For --dry-run, also log the expected stack virtual
state/action the deployment would go with.

Closes-bug: #1778505

Change-Id: I55dc83acb2ed5ee07b4cf57e25135e6201589ac4
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Track fake stack updates for standalone/UC deploy

Puppet relies on stack_action UPDATE for some cases.
Track the ephemeral heat stacks fake state for tripleo
undercloud/standalone deployments to match the puppet
expectations. For such deployments, the heat stack
state is a fake (virtual), as we never
update but always create a new ephemeral heat stack.

When the deployment is finished w/o errors, create the mark
file (unique to the stack name) that is used to indicate to
puppet the stack_action has been changed from CREATE to
UPDATE. The indication is done via a drop-in file with
top level override containing either 'StackAction: CREATE'
or 'UPDATE'. The drop-in is created in the working/templates
directory and named <Stack_name>-stack-vstate-dropin.yaml.

When the deployment fails, remove the mark file, so
the serial re-deployments will be considered as creating
a stack. The --force-stack-update flag keeps the mark file
instead, so the serial re-deployment will be
considered (virtually) updating the heat stack.

For the --output-only mode, only warn users to control
the stack virtual state manually. The state is considered
CREATE, unless there is --force-stack-update specified.

For --dry-run, also log the expected stack virtual
state/action the deployment would go with.

Closes-bug: #1778505

Change-Id: I55dc83acb2ed5ee07b4cf57e25135e6201589ac4
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
storage_vnx_pool_name is incorrect for VNX cinder driver.

Correct option is storage_vnx_pool_names, so environments and puppet
service yamls need to be changed.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/572720/
Closes-bug: #1775752

Change-Id: I98ec997847443673b49552d1223238bc9da03cf4
(cherry picked from commit 1fa441479b378a448c78e7a1a354f46850f2b4cd)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Remove all glance nfs changes from puppet-tripleo

Since, mounting nfs would run via ansible in t-h-t,
puppet-tripleo glance nfs_mount.pp would no longer be
used.

Hence removing all glance nfs related part from here.

Depends-On: I232577643c26d7eb0162c09b3c394b7f3e161154
Change-Id: I617c38266d17fdf8cade660207e1e369dcd54fdb

commit_message:
Add mistral job to rotate passwords on the overcloud

This commit adds worflows to allow deployers to change
passwords post-install.  There are several options:

rotate_passwords: generates new passwords for all passwords
    except those which need to be handled specially
rotate_passwords + password_list: generates only the
    specified passwords

All data is stored in the plan.  To be propagated, the
overcloud must then be re-deployed.

Change-Id: I0ef8be542c3e4969e1bd3193e2e4bf7d4be73f55

commit_message:
Fix regression in undercloud upgrade cell_v2 setup

For cell0 the order needs to be create_cell, map_cell0, dbsync.
I67c50fd5a5d2f4841ab26bce796a33efce0510b2 reversed this, as a result the cell0
tables are not created as it does not exist when the dbsync runs.

Change-Id: I8774865a573bf9c63190d3df8aaca34089755549
Closes-Bug: 1778788

commit_message:
Make ovn gates voting

This commit makes the ovn gates that are non on the experimental queue
voting. It has been stable for a while and I think that it's about time
we move them to voting.

Change-Id: Ice8bfcf899f05bb5fa5d06daf04e5796ab8870cc

Mention server status in api-ref when rebuild

Add description about server status in active, shutoff,
error can accept a rebuild action.

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

For more details information, please refer to:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

In order to pass the requirements check, a new lower bound is set for the
'pyasn1' and 'requests' packages.

Change-Id: I1be4adb97fb3a37968afb9628fe3a7346cc55ccc

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-20 19:23:34.000000000', 'message': 'Solidfire: Fix pylint errors for class decorators

A couple decorators used within the Solidfire driver were defined
as class methods rather than their own functions. This results in
the pylint errors:

"Method should have \"self\" as first argument"

Since these do not need access to self, there is no reason they
should be class methods. This moves them out to be their own
functions.

Change-Id: Ia4da36987783fb0e3f2c44857a3cf9d586c5e769
'}]
commit_message:
Solidfire: Fix pylint errors for class decorators

A couple decorators used within the Solidfire driver were defined
as class methods rather than their own functions. This results in
the pylint errors:

"Method should have \"self\" as first argument"

Since these do not need access to self, there is no reason they
should be class methods. This moves them out to be their own
functions.

Change-Id: Ia4da36987783fb0e3f2c44857a3cf9d586c5e769

subject: Alembic migrations for all SQL script revisions
messages:
[{'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-04-24 13:51:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-04-24 14:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

A few notes on testing this (assumes a Devstack environment):

First of all, create gold standard SQL scripts for testing against:

```
cd /opt/stack/monasca-api
for rev in $(git log devstack/files/schema/mon_mysql.sql | grep '^commit' | cut -d ' ' -f 2);
do
  git checkout $rev devstack/files/schema/mon_mysql.sql
  echo 'drop database mon; create database mon;' | mysql
  mysql < devstack/files/schema/mon_mysql.sql
  mysqldump --no-data mon > /tmp/indb_${rev}.sql
done
git checkout devstack/files/schema/mon_mysql.sql
```
Next, incrementally apply the alembic migrations for each migration ID <migration>, resetting the database before each migration:

```
cd /opt/stack/monasca-api/monasca_api/db
echo 'drop database mon; create database mon;' | mysql
alembic upgrade <migration>;
mysqldump --no-data mon > /tmp/current.sql
```

Diff /tmp/current.sql against the corresponding git revision's database dump in /tmp for every migration. You should only see the following differences:

1) Line ordering
2) A missing `alembic_version` table which does not occur in the SQL scripts."}, {'account_id': 26702, 'date': '2018-04-24 14:21:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Good job!'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-04-25 13:13:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-24 13:51:06.000000000', 'message': 'Alembic migrations for all SQL script revisions

This commit adds

* An alembic environment for running database migrations
* Alembic database migrations for all revisions
  of the legacy SQL script currently being used to set up the
  Monasca database.
* The get_all_metadata() function for exposing full data model
  metadata. This function is needed generating migrations from
  the current state of the model and should be kept up to date
  as the model is being extended.

Change-Id: I41b4577d8334791f712177348cadfe9b07b62ef1
Story: 2001654
Task: 14339

commit_message:
Alembic migrations for all SQL script revisions

This commit adds

* An alembic environment for running database migrations
* Alembic database migrations for all revisions
  of the legacy SQL script currently being used to set up the
  Monasca database.
* The get_all_metadata() function for exposing full data model
  metadata. This function is needed generating migrations from
  the current state of the model and should be kept up to date
  as the model is being extended.

Change-Id: I41b4577d8334791f712177348cadfe9b07b62ef1
Story: 2001654
Task: 14339

commit_message:
Add sensu rabbitmq port

This allows us to set the rabbitmq port to use for sensu seperatly
from rabbitmq.  Since we dont use the same rabbitmq for sensu.

Change-Id: I3720dfa3e67d30c1e9a4043d20b24bbe9b76d606

commit_message:
When preventing insecure endpoints be more careful

We only want to forward when we can't do it locally, and still with TLS.

This requires that we have the port open on 127.0.0.1 so it can be
forwarded. So far only doing nova/neutron/keystone/glance but all
services would need this change for the mode to work.

This required a lot more logic, so whitespace is added to help read
through the conditional logic.

For memcached, this isn't so much about security but just the way
the haproxy configuration works when using secure/insecure endpoints.
One will probably want to disable haproxy+memcached when using
secure endpoints.

Change-Id: I726087f26814c4fddcfd20be02790eceb37ed9d3
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/556978/

commit_message:
Add packages required for osprofiler

The following packages are required in-order to run osprofiler.
these packages will provide deployers the ability to profile
a service on demand should they choose to enable the profile
functionality.

messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-06-28 13:57:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-06-28 16:24:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 13404, 'date': '2018-06-29 09:07:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-02 09:07:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14805, 'date': '2018-07-02 17:59:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-28 13:57:43.000000000', 'message': 'Move database creation into role (designate)

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we remove the group_vars which were duplicated from the
role, and remove the DB setup tasks as they are no longer required.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/578808
Change-Id: I3d96a5d0bbec355d6edec25c4b567e4399946dc0
'}]
commit_message:
Move database creation into role (designate)

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we remove the group_vars which were duplicated from the
role, and remove the DB setup tasks as they are no longer required.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/578808
Change-Id: I3d96a5d0bbec355d6edec25c4b567e4399946dc0

commit_message:
Promote puppet-4 beaker jobs to nonvoting check

It will be easier to get an overview of how compatible the puppet
modules are with puppet 4 if they all have running puppet 4 jobs that
don't need to be triggered manually.

Change-Id: I91bd73194efdfee7e2ccc34890f6183abbfe877c

commit_message:
NEC driver: Delete max volumes per pool limit.

Currently, the max number of volumes (logical disks) per pool is
limited to 1024.
The limitation is eliminated in new firmware of NEC Storage.
This patch deletes the limitation.

Change-Id: I0c5a06714725eb2b2e6eb689fe4be9990aa3707b
(cherry picked from commit ecfd4d393a12b408b9961358841c70d20b476f49)

commit_message:
Remove pause to fix upstream bug

Effectively the pause module requires ncurses, while the tests are using
the pause module, and that's nice to have it's not required.

See issue [0] for more information.

[0] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/42004

Change-Id: I172d161c4cf55741982ca8ced36a59407c70ba99
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

subject: Add EPEL repo for nginx packages on CentOS tests
messages:
[{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-07-02 07:00:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-07-02 07:33:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-02 08:01:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

I am fine with that, I'd rather have the title rephrased to be less scary, and I'd like to see other ppl chime in."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-07-02 08:05:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-02 08:08:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

Okay for me, waiting for expert's review."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-07-02 18:16:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm torn about this, on one side you have a fully working implementation, however on the other, we've kinda taken the use-upstream-from-nginx path in repo_server role.

Ideally, maintaining the same 'solution' for the problem in both sides would be the ideal thing to do.  But I really don't want to bug you to redo most of your work.

Do you have spare cycles to make this use nginx as we've done in repo_server or is this something that's a bit hard because of time constraints?"}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-02 18:17:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-07-02 18:20:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I'm torn about this, on one side you have a fully working
 > implementation, however on the other, we've kinda taken the
 > use-upstream-from-nginx path in repo_server role.
 > 
 > Ideally, maintaining the same 'solution' for the problem in both
 > sides would be the ideal thing to do.  But I really don't want to
 > bug you to redo most of your work.
 > 
 > Do you have spare cycles to make this use nginx as we've done in
 > repo_server or is this something that's a bit hard because of time
 > constraints?

++ I agree that getting this to us the upstream nginx repo would make the most sense however this change seems to make the repo server tests happy for the time being so I'm included to push this through and circle back on our strategy moving forward with regard to centos."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-07-02 19:49:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

EPEL was selected as there’s an infra mirror for it, and nginx here is only being used to provide a simple web server for tests to download from. It’s not used in production - that would be determined by the repo server role.'}]

Add EPEL repo for nginx packages on CentOS tests

In order to have access to nginx, we need to add the EPEL
repository.

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208
Change-Id: I963ccbb3353387adb724ee5f5630978ac9fd4f9e

[{'created': '2018-06-25 21:41:34.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up unnecessary test params in test_rbd

Unit test was added that copied a test using ddt for supplied
values passed in, but the new test did not used ddt. This just
moves the values of those parameters into the body of the test.
It keeps the variable names to help keep the intent of the
values clear.

Change-Id: I5148f9500b0578dae457a9b561def8568165fbd1
'}]
commit_message:
Clean up unnecessary test params in test_rbd

Unit test was added that copied a test using ddt for supplied
values passed in, but the new test did not used ddt. This just
moves the values of those parameters into the body of the test.
It keeps the variable names to help keep the intent of the
values clear.

Change-Id: I5148f9500b0578dae457a9b561def8568165fbd1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-29 19:38:29.000000000', 'message': "Fix quota error when deleting temporary volume

When deleting a volume, always use the admin context to fetch the
admin_metadata that indicates whether it's a temporary volume.

This fixes a bug where a non-admin user failed to retrieve the
admin_metadata, which caused the volume to not be treated as temporary.
This, in turn, caused quota usage to be incorrectly updated.

Closes-Bug: #1778774
Change-Id: I8e6b0c726dc6498b28795a1ea0520ef05e53f047
(cherry picked from commit 8d9f8629013bcb880fb3e33f03b274c10befdab0)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix quota error when deleting temporary volume

When deleting a volume, always use the admin context to fetch the
admin_metadata that indicates whether it's a temporary volume.

This fixes a bug where a non-admin user failed to retrieve the
admin_metadata, which caused the volume to not be treated as temporary.
This, in turn, caused quota usage to be incorrectly updated.

Closes-Bug: #1778774
Change-Id: I8e6b0c726dc6498b28795a1ea0520ef05e53f047
(cherry picked from commit 8d9f8629013bcb880fb3e33f03b274c10befdab0)

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208
Change-Id: Ib9a986352cf525d7d78ff3cfe1c63d74e30bff8d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-28 14:03:47.000000000', 'message': "Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'magnum_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable 'magnum_galera_address' which
has been used for a long time, but never documented. A bunch of unused
variables have also been removed.

Change-Id: I81263f316503c12f8e7b35e6ba9be12cc72cda1a
"}, {'created': '2018-06-28 16:13:44.000000000', 'message': "Move database creation into role

of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'magnum_db_setup_host'

commit_message:
Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'magnum_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable 'magnum_galera_address' which
has been used for a long time, but never documented. A bunch of unused
variables have also been removed.

Change-Id: I81263f316503c12f8e7b35e6ba9be12cc72cda1a

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208

commit_message:
Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'octavia_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable 'octavia_galera_address' which
has been used for a long time, but never documented. A bunch of unused
variables have also been removed.

Change-Id: I89a5a519e35058ad65ba3dbf31051e848894b35d

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208
Change-Id: I83efde2ee1aa243ba71b7774a2de780ec5f4c3e6

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-28 15:40:20.000000000', 'message': "Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'rally_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable 'rally_galera_address' which
has been used for a long time, but never documented. A bunch of unused
variables have also been removed.

Change-Id: Ifb89e35e3acaef33ce4ce24b3f5affc6c4e8e494

commit_message:
Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'rally_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable 'rally_galera_address' which
has been used for a long time, but never documented. A bunch of unused
variables have also been removed.

Change-Id: Ifb89e35e3acaef33ce4ce24b3f5affc6c4e8e494

commit_message:
Add mechanism for cookie-based sessions in endpoints.

In order to allow SAML integration, we need to persist sessions for
the Keystone public API. Rather than use a one-off resource, this
patch introduces a generic mechanism for adding cookie-based sessions
to any endpoint that uses the endpoint resource and uses that mechanism
to provide a session persistence option for the Keystone public API.

Change-Id: I7e1c9a4ddc8b849b487b863635b8c45fc935a751

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

For more details information, please refer to:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

In order to pass the requirements check, a new lower bound is set for the
'pyasn1' and 'requests' packages.

Change-Id: Ia136d992b96c92f80a6b07448a48855ed324fb9d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-16 18:54:14.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor list_users and related functions

list_users has some excess looping that could be consolidated to gain
some performance improvements. This change consolidates a few of these
excess loops for list_users as well as the utility functions.

commit_message:
Refactor list_users and related functions

list_users has some excess looping that could be consolidated to gain
some performance improvements. This change refactors a few of these
loops for _set_domain_id_and_mapping as well as removing the conf
object which does not need to be passed around.

Also added another federated user to the list_users test in
test_backends for additional coverage to show that this change does not
break functionality.

Co-Authored-By: wangxiyuan <wangxiyuan@huawei.com>

Change-Id: I9a80149aa10930a0d82c304f9e59d96f1dbaf1d3
Related-Bug: #1689888

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

For more details information, please refer to:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

In order to pass the requirements check, a new lower bound is set for the
'pyasn1' and 'requests' packages.

Change-Id: If44929dbe402c4249235a7fcb9226b97f20d0e43

commit_message:
config: Add support for config from environment variables

The spec proposes a model for getting configuration/option
settings/values from environment variables in the execution
environment.

blueprint config-from-environment

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208
Change-Id: I13c1433377d8697162ac57122651a370c0971f6f

commit_message:
Convert oslo.policy to using stestr

With the upgrade to oslotest 3.6.0 [0], testr no longer works [1].
This is because oslotest no longer requires testr and we don't depend
on it directly in oslo.policy. Let's switch to using stestr, too!
Everyone's doing it...

[0] https://github.com/openstack/requirements/commit/d5a3c58f7195517a6083032e41b702c2a0aca431
[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslotest/commit/897823fbd61ae9ba015af38e9fed5a5728de64c2

Change-Id: If5d502774ec0d756bcecabbcfa74f7af70fb28c6

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208

Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-30 20:12:41.000000000', 'message': "Check for migrated UUID in SolidFire delete

Migration of volumes kinda screws up the use of ID as the
reference to use for deleting volumes.

If a volume is migrated, the UUID (ID) gets swapped and no
longer matches the UUID the volume had when it was initially
created on the back end device.  The result is that deletion
of that volume fails on the back end because the handle to the
new UUID doesn't exist.

On the other hand, you also have to be careful in dealing with
and cleaning up volumes migrated off of your back end device for
the same types of reasons.

This change just adds an additional check in the SF driver so that
we are querying the back end device for the ID and the name_id.

This way we make sure if the volume is on our device we clean it up.

Change-Id: I60f8e8864f236fb92dd03560576377f1a0bdd82b
Closes-Bug: #1733967
(cherry picked from commit 0e6ee1b1df38059f338ebd93c605dfb51a93a8a5)

commit_message:
Check for migrated UUID in SolidFire delete

Migration of volumes kinda screws up the use of ID as the
reference to use for deleting volumes.

If a volume is migrated, the UUID (ID) gets swapped and no
longer matches the UUID the volume had when it was initially
created on the back end device.  The result is that deletion
of that volume fails on the back end because the handle to the
new UUID doesn't exist.

On the other hand, you also have to be careful in dealing with
and cleaning up volumes migrated off of your back end device for
the same types of reasons.

This change just adds an additional check in the SF driver so that
we are querying the back end device for the ID and the name_id.

This way we make sure if the volume is on our device we clean it up.

Change-Id: I60f8e8864f236fb92dd03560576377f1a0bdd82b
Closes-Bug: #1733967
(cherry picked from commit 0e6ee1b1df38059f338ebd93c605dfb51a93a8a5)

commit_message:
Pass network's dns_domain to dnsmasq conf

The Neutron API exposes the 'dns_domain' attribute on the
Network model. Presently, deployments using the DHCP
agent ignore this attribute when resolving DNS queries
between instances. This patch changes that so that
the DHCP agent will pass on the dns_domain to the
network's dnsmasq process, in turn passing it to
instances.

UpgradeImpact
Closes-Bug: 1774710
Change-Id: I6120d504959631f084d63458f6e9dada0dc5cbdf

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208
Change-Id: I8dcbb9d2a6d170572098acd74de389929902fae5

commit_message:
Update --http-boot default for containerized undercloud

Changes the default value of --http-boot to match what is expected by
the containerized undercloud which will be the default in Rocky.

Change-Id: Ibfccc9b98ff503224438fdedf484383cf56194fc
Depends-On: I9e754a7efff4113c50c0c825d58461e6bc94aa24
Closes-Bug: #1669186

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208
Change-Id: Ifaf5805df73eb8ea0192015c51583b03c639dff8

subject: Move database creation into role
messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-06-12 19:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-07-02 09:12:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2018-07-02 15:07:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-12 19:40:07.000000000', 'message': "Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'cloudkitty_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable cloudkitty_galera_address which
has been used for a long time, but never documented.

Change-Id: I7bb3f38556558ef14723361d3672a1d06f839b52
"}]
commit_message:
Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'cloudkitty_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable cloudkitty_galera_address which
has been used for a long time, but never documented.

Change-Id: I7bb3f38556558ef14723361d3672a1d06f839b52

to update the document of oneview after the removal
of classic drivers.

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208
Change-Id: I1f61d9b31f983eeb21376166b80aca400235ced1

commit_message:
Add shade & python-keystoneclient to the tox venv

In order to reduce the packages required to pip install on to the hosts,
we install the extra library into the ansible-runtime venv so that tasks
interacting with keystone using our keystone module can do so by using
localhost delegation. Using this strategy, the library does not need to
be installed on the target host.

This has been done in the integrated repo in [1] and [2].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/557351
[2] https://review.openstack.org/568141

Change-Id: I672ae0f4adbf54a7d71e06e6715d562069fda877

Though a `swift_operator_role` variable exists to allow specifying an
operator role other than `swiftoperator`, it is not applied to all
uses of the role, eg the proxy-server.conf template.

commit_message:
Replace swiftoperator role with swift_operator_role variable

Though a `swift_operator_role` variable exists to allow specifying an
operator role other than `swiftoperator`, it is not applied to all
uses of the role, eg the proxy-server.conf template.

Replace all remaining hard-coded references to the `swiftoperator`
role with the `swift_operator_role` variable.

Change-Id: Ie6db872cc2b7a1b1a90d9a690ee08937a9cab785
Signed-off-by: Corey Wright <corey.wright@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox changes in this review will need to be replicated
to all other roles. All other roles will also need their
'test-requirements.txt' file removed unless they have
something special in them which is not common.

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

commit_message:
Do not grant caps if pool name is empty

The openstack_keys map can have permissions for an empty pool
which results in an invalid kerying.

Co-Authored-By: Giulio Fidente <gfidente@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: 1776987
(cherry picked from commit Ic5ae53d9ab52ea5e7c3f75a240a7a7f4bb5632ba)

Change-Id: Iaaa09032707f9c9bf722521dd8efb97a1f142804

commit_message:
Add overcloud-secure-uefi element

This is the equivalent of the overcloud-secure element,
but is defined to generate images that are capable to boot
from UEFI.

Change-Id: If9e0504438632f1a22b45b7c95e7bfb8cb6f41d3

messages: [{'account_id': 28521, 'date': '2018-07-02 15:02:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-07-02 15:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28521, 'date': '2018-07-02 15:03:36.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nAlready done.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-02 15:02:59.000000000', 'message': "Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208
Change-Id: I7e0d525c2203ede273887d6a0e32ed8e6fd7598b
"}]
commit_message:
Use tests repo for common role test requirements

Using tox for requirements management requires in-repo
requirements files for all our repositories. Rather than
do that, we make use of the tests repo to capture our
common requirements and use this to install them.

This reduces our review requirement rate and simplifies
maintenance for us for the tox config. It also makes it
usable with 'Depends-On', which is marvellous!

The tox requirements definitions for docs/releasenotes
builds are left in-place as those are standard entries
across the community. If that changes at some point, we
can re-assess those entries too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579208
Change-Id: I7e0d525c2203ede273887d6a0e32ed8e6fd7598b

commit_message:
Add option to override confirmation in yaml-nic-config-2-script.py

This change adds the option to override the user input confirmation
to overwrite the nic template file. This is required when the script
is used inside automated jobs.

Closes-bug: 1770296

Change-Id: Ic8275bb3a944e503c73ab06c3d5140ea3563c0a6
(cherry picked from commit 553554ad72688e1ee41c0991d6e23d31621117a1)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-20 07:24:04.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup unused key-value in the attribute of l3

The external_fixed_ips is defined "convert_list_to" and "default"
in external_gateway_info attribute of l3 and l3_ext_gw_mode.
However, the "type:dict_or_nodata" validator doesn't manage
"convert_list_to" and "default" keys.
They are unused definitions so this patch removes them.

Change-Id: I9078a655adfd3a3567e4b4bd878e41ab68b1e1f2
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup unused key-value in the attribute of l3

The external_fixed_ips is defined "convert_list_to" and "default"
in external_gateway_info attribute of l3 and l3_ext_gw_mode.
However, the "type:dict_or_nodata" validator doesn't manage
"convert_list_to" and "default" keys.
They are unused definitions so this patch removes them.

Change-Id: I9078a655adfd3a3567e4b4bd878e41ab68b1e1f2

I need to limit to number of dhcp per network because all my computes nodes are network node (because dvr). When a lot of dhcp are used per network, port usage is too high. Need to tweek quotas...'}, {'account_id': 23182, 'date': '2018-07-02 14:47:39.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Using conf overrides is enough, ex:
cat /etc/openstack_deploy/conf.d/neutron.yml 
---

global_overrides:
  neutron_neutron_conf_overrides:
    DEFAULT:
        dhcp_agents_per_network: "3"'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-02 12:30:03.000000000', 'message': "Add KURYR_K8S_LBAAS_USE_OCTAVIA=False to LBaaS job

Turns out in plugin.sh we're depending from aformentioned variable being
set. It defaults to True, so when it wasn't set for LBaaS v2 jobs, we've
ended up not doing some of the stuff we should, e.g. creating a K8s
Service for Neutron router IP.

This commit fixes that as well as some minor issues in code creating the
Service for Neutron router IP. Please note that while it might have been
useful to just switch to use `is_service_enabled q-lbaasv2`, we're in
the process of deprecation of LBaaS v2 support, so I decided to just fix
it the easy way.

Change-Id: If962d9df8780ed342e6658d2d9939863ea7e6ed3
Closes-Bug: 1779312
"}]
commit_message:
Add KURYR_K8S_LBAAS_USE_OCTAVIA=False to LBaaS job

Turns out in plugin.sh we're depending from aformentioned variable being
set. It defaults to True, so when it wasn't set for LBaaS v2 jobs, we've
ended up not doing some of the stuff we should, e.g. creating a K8s
Service for Neutron router IP.

This commit fixes that as well as some minor issues in code creating the
Service for Neutron router IP. Please note that while it might have been
useful to just switch to use `is_service_enabled q-lbaasv2`, we're in
the process of deprecation of LBaaS v2 support, so I decided to just fix
it the easy way.

Change-Id: If962d9df8780ed342e6658d2d9939863ea7e6ed3
Closes-Bug: 1779312

commit_message:
Restore openstack-ansible-upgrade-ubuntu-xenial

Without this patch, nova upgrades are not tested.
As a reminder, Master and Queens were simulatenously broken
together due to the SPICE url change. We can now bring the
upgrades back now that the SPICE url change has been merged
in Queens [1].

The fact we do not test upgrades is a problem, as we could
miss an important upstream change, or break our upgrades
ourselves without noticing.

This patches solves the problem.

[1]: I5639ebee2d232fdac3f5fe2d38e9a54d2ff8c03a

Change-Id: I31e874ecad4525e57b85f2b09a556124a8f8829d

Add Magnum cluster support

Add CRUD support for Magnum COE clusters. Please refer Magnum's
API ref doc for the API design[1].

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/container-infrastructure-management

commit_message:
placement: Return new provider from POST /rps

To facilitate opaqueness of resource provider generation internals, we
need to return the (initial) generation when a provider is created. For
consistency with other APIs, we will do this by returning the entire
resource provider record (which includes the generation) from POST
/resource_providers.

Change-Id: I8624e194fe0173531c5aa2119c903e3c68b8c6cd
blueprint: generation-from-create-provider

commit_message:
Do not build cryptography

Cryptography is shipping with wheels [1], and recent bugs for
dynamic linking in wheel building [2] should be fixed now.

We should therefore use the wheels.

[1]: https://pypi.org/project/cryptography/#files
[2]: https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/pull/3811

Change-Id: I1b7e1ee1e127569b488d7202ae601ee17701d3f0

Yeah I've got no issues with doing that, I'll look into it today, thanks!"}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2016-11-02 09:26:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

> This is coming up around other issues: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/389608/5
 > 
 > Prehaps it makes sense to keep the old volume info about.

I just commented there that I couldn't see the need for stashing the original source host BDMs. I see how this could be useful in terms of this rollback issue but I'm still not sure it's something we really need to do.

 > But long term Cinder is taking control of storing the
 > connection_info, so we shouldn't need to worry about this stuff any
 > more. But thats a while away, and we need something in the mean
 > time.

In this situation it already does as the destination has possibly overwritten the connection_info originally used by the source. I'd rather just call out to cinder again to have this refreshed for the source than have Nova stash an older copy somewhere for use during a rollback."}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2016-11-03 12:23:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

> I'd prefer to put this into migrate_data object as a field instead,
 > what do you think?

Finally had a look at this and before I start hacking away I wanted to confirm that I'm heading in the correct direction here. 

Reviewing the current LibvirtLiveMigrateData object we are already stashing LibvirtLiveMigrateBDMInfo objects that represent each volume attached to the instance. These are populated via  block_device_info_get_mapping using block_device_info in pre_live_migration. 

Would it be worthwhile introducing a LibvirtLiveMigrateBlockDeviceInfo object that models the original block_device_info and in turn contains the list of LibvirtLiveMigrateBDMInfo objects? Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2016-11-03 13:41:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2016-11-03 13:49:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Code-Review-1

So I am thinking through how we should fix this.

I believe we can do something like evacuate:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/a686185fc02ec421fd27270a343c19f668b95da6

But I need to think through how that would work here.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2016-11-03 14:00:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

 > https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/a686185fc02ec421fd27270a343c19f668b95da6
 > 
 > But I need to think through how that would work here.

I don't think this is going to help, we already disconnect_volume and terminate_connection for each BDM via a call to the destination in _rollback_live_migration and as a result are using the valid local connector.

This change is really focused with providing rollback_live_migration_at_destination with the destination's version of block_device_info ahead of refreshing this and the associated bdms on the source."}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2016-11-03 14:53:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

The following change being an example of there where we refresh block_device_info on the source after the RPC cast to rollback_live_migration_at_destination :

Agreed, I've given up trying to stash block_device_info after looking at the virt driver rollback_live_migration_at_destination implementations. AFAICT none of them actually need it as we have already disconnected and terminated all volume connections by the time we are calling this.

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-07-07 12:15:00.000000000', 'message': 'WIP - compute: Refresh connection_info on migration rollback

Previously changes made to bdm.connection_info on the destination host
during pre_live_migration would not be reverted on the source when
rolling back. As a result future attempts to connect to the bdm could
either fail or incorrectly connect to a different volume depending on
the volume backend being used.

These changes are now reverted by calling for a refresh of
connection_info on the source host while rolling back a migration.

Closes-bug: #1419577
Change-Id: If28f86077f6d675faee75727cc6834665a8437bd

'}, {'created': '2016-10-19 16:17:31.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Refresh connection_info on migration rollback

Previously changes made to the connection_info of bdms on the destination host
during pre_live_migration would not be reverted on the source when
rolling back. As a result future attempts to connect to these bdm could
either fail or incorrectly connect to a different volume depending on
the volume backend being used.

To correct this bdms are now refreshed on the source after the call has
been made to the destination to rollback. To ensure that these two
events do not race against each other the original block_device_info
that includes connection_info for each bdm is also provided as an
additional argument to the compute rpcapi call
rollback_live_migration_at_destination.

Closes-bug: #1419577
Change-Id: If28f86077f6d675faee75727cc6834665a8437bd
'}, {'created': '2016-10-20 09:31:25.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Refresh connection_info on migration rollback

Previously changes made to the connection_info of bdms on the destination host
during pre_live_migration would not be reverted on the source when
rolling back. As a result future attempts to connect to these bdm could
either fail or incorrectly connect to a different volume depending on
the volume backend being used.

To correct this bdms are now refreshed on the source after the call has
been made to the destination to rollback. To ensure that these two
events do not race against each other the original block_device_info
that includes connection_info for each bdm is also provided as an
additional argument to the compute rpcapi call
rollback_live_migration_at_destination.

Closes-bug: #1419577
Change-Id: If28f86077f6d675faee75727cc6834665a8437bd
'}, {'created': '2016-10-20 13:16:18.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Provide block_device_info during LM rollback

This first step in resolving bug#1419577 ensures that the source
provides the destination with the current block_device_info when calling
for a live migration rollback.

In Pike this will then allow the source to refresh each bdm,
potentially reverting any changes made to the connection_info by the
destination host, resolving bug#1419577.

'}, {'created': '2016-10-26 14:42:53.000000000', 'message': 'compute: Provide block_device_info during LM rollback

When rolling back live migrations no attempt is made to revert changes
made to the connection_info of bdms by the destination. As such future
use of this connection_info on the source after the rollback can
potentially cause failures if the required connection details differ
between the two hosts.

The first step in correcting this issue is to ensure that the
destination does not fetch a copy of block_device_info for the instance
during the rollback. This will allow a future fix to then refresh the
bdms on the source without racing against the destination host.

Partial-Bug #1419577
Change-Id: If28f86077f6d675faee75727cc6834665a8437bd

potentially cause failures if the required connection details differ
between the two hosts.

The first step in correcting this issue is to ensure that the
destination does not fetch a copy of block_device_info for the instance
during the rollback. This will allow a future fix to then refresh the
bdms on the source without racing against the destination host.

Partial-Bug #1419577
Change-Id: If28f86077f6d675faee75727cc6834665a8437bd
'}, {'created': '2016-11-07 19:53:50.000000000', 'message': "WIP Compute: Reset bdm connection_info during LM rollback

When rolling back live migration attempts changes made to each bdms'
connection_info are not reverted. As such future use of this
connection_info on the source can potentially cause failures if the
connection details are host specific.

As 15eaba6b28e has now introduced the stashing of the original bdms on
the source host during pre_live_migrate we can now reset the
connection_info for each bdm during a rollback.

This change also drops the use of block_device_info when calling
rollback_live_migration_at_destination. This is not required as
_rollback_live_migration has already called remove_volume_connection for
each volume bdm on the destination prior to making this call.

TODOs
=====

- Does block_device_info need to be removed from the rpcapi for
  rollback_live_migration_at_destination?
- Verify that virt drivers don't fail with this missing.
  - libvirt - calls destroy() and shouldn't fail
  - hyperv - calls destroy() and shouldn't fail
  - xenapi - iterates over [] and shouldn't fail

Closes-Bug #1419577
Change-Id: If28f86077f6d675faee75727cc6834665a8437bd

_rollback_live_migration has already called remove_volume_connection for
each volume bdm on the destination prior to making this call.

Closes-Bug #1419577
Change-Id: If28f86077f6d675faee75727cc6834665a8437bd

commit_message:
Compute: Reset bdm connection_info during LM rollback

When rolling back live migration attempts changes made to each bdms'
connection_info are not reverted. As such future use of this
connection_info on the source can potentially cause failures if the
connection details are host specific.

As 15eaba6b28e has now introduced the stashing of the original bdms on
the source host during pre_live_migrate we can now reset the
connection_info for each bdm during a rollback.

This change also drops the use of block_device_info when calling
rollback_live_migration_at_destination. This is not required as
_rollback_live_migration has already called remove_volume_connection for
each volume bdm on the destination prior to making this call.

Closes-Bug #1419577
Change-Id: If28f86077f6d675faee75727cc6834665a8437bd

[{'created': '2018-06-18 15:00:33.000000000', 'message': "Fix regression when listing build_requests with marker and ip filter

Change Ic02206e887e3fea7752d615bbed680510c482097 attempted
to optimize the GET /servers flow by skipping filtering on
build requests if the ip or ip6 filters were used, since
servers that are not yet scheduled (build requests) can have
ips. However, if a marker is provided and the marker is in the
build_requests table, we fail to look there and then check the
cells for the marker, which won't exist and result in a 400
MarkerNotFound error.

This fixes the issue by *not* skipping build requests if there
is a marker specified. A functional test is added which will
show the 400 MarkerNotFound error if the code fix is removed.

Change-Id: Ibdd157d06252c3c0219539ec798c8d9d3a8ae26f
Closes-Bug: #1777458

commit_message:
Fix regression when listing build_requests with marker and ip filter

Change Ic02206e887e3fea7752d615bbed680510c482097 attempted
to optimize the GET /servers flow by skipping filtering on
build requests if the ip or ip6 filters were used, since
servers that are not yet scheduled (build requests) can't have
ips. However, if a marker is provided and the marker is in the
build_requests table, we fail to look there and then check the
cells for the marker, which won't exist and result in a 400
MarkerNotFound error.

This fixes the issue by *not* skipping build requests if there
is a marker specified. A functional test is added which will
show the 400 MarkerNotFound error if the code fix is removed.

Change-Id: Ibdd157d06252c3c0219539ec798c8d9d3a8ae26f
Closes-Bug: #1777458

this looks logical, and the command found my mtu ok'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-06-27 11:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This patch is o.k., but I think it is not enough to fix all ds-gate based jobs.

We have PUBLIC_BRIDGE_MTU=1450 in http://logs.openstack.org/46/578146/3/check/neutron-grenade-multinode/2b09ca4/logs/new/local.conf.txt.gz but no such setting in http://logs.openstack.org/46/578146/3/check/neutron-grenade/b3dc6e7/logs/new/local.conf.txt.gz

It would be really great if we could run these jobs on a node with reduced MTU in order to verify them.

A bit unrelated, I don't understand why we run all the tempest-full* jobs here, they don't seem to have any relationship with devstack-gate anymore."}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-06-27 22:47:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> This patch is o.k., but I think it is not enough to fix all ds-gate
 > based jobs.
 > 
 > We have PUBLIC_BRIDGE_MTU=1450 in http://logs.openstack.org/46/578146/3/check/neutron-grenade-multinode/2b09ca4/logs/new/local.conf.txt.gz
 > but no such setting in http://logs.openstack.org/46/578146/3/check/neutron-grenade/b3dc6e7/logs/new/local.conf.txt.gz
 > 

I think this happens because we only need to set the MTU when running multinode as we have the infra provided overlay in that case. The single node jobs do not have any nova+neutron VM traffic leave the host so they can use arbitrarily sized MTUs.

 > It would be really great if we could run these jobs on a node with
 > reduced MTU in order to verify them.

While I agree this would be helpful I think if this works on systems with MTUs of 1500 and we don't regress them we can continue to fine tune this if necessary when running on lower MTU clouds again (currently disabled).

 > 
 > A bit unrelated, I don't understand why we run all the
 > tempest-full* jobs here, they don't seem to have any relationship
 > with devstack-gate anymore.

I expect we pulled those in via a template we are using. I agree we should clean that up."}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2018-06-28 14:36:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-06-28 15:12:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

There were failures on single-node jobs, e.g. neutron-tempest-linuxbridge. Neutron since some weeks errors out when it is told to create a port with MTU 1500 on an external bridge which inherits the ens3 MTU of 1450.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-06-28 19:34:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-06-28 19:36:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> There were failures on single-node jobs, e.g. neutron-tempest-linuxbridge.
 > Neutron since some weeks errors out when it is told to create a
 > port with MTU 1500 on an external bridge which inherits the ens3
 > MTU of 1450.

I think that is a bug in the linuxbridge setup from devstack then. It shouldn't connect the external interface by default. It should operate in its own bubble like the ovs job does. Devstack-gate doesn't have anything to do with that I don't think."}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-06-29 18:47:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-07-02 00:55:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-07-02 09:50:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

O.k., let's proceed here and check the single-node jobs once we can test on smaller MTU again."}]

overlay networks. List all "real" interfaces with a permament mac addr
then use the smallest MTU less 50 bytes for vxlan overhead.

We only consider "real" interfaces so that we can run this multiple

Change-Id: If163bf211570e690e255cc3ef6888d9e0cba19b5
'}]
commit_message:
Dynamically determine overlay MTU

Some clouds we run on no longer have MTUs of 1500 on their interfaces
and are smaller. We dynamically determine the MTU we should use on the
overlay networks. List all "real" interfaces with a permament mac addr
then use the smallest MTU less 50 bytes for vxlan overhead.

We only consider "real" interfaces so that we can run this multiple
times for separate overlays without perpetually decreasing the MTU due
to finding the lower MTU we just configured.

Change-Id: If163bf211570e690e255cc3ef6888d9e0cba19b5

commit_message:
Simplify instance name generation

Support for the 'multi_instance_display_name_template' option was
removed in commit 0e43002c9 and booting multiple instances now will
simply result in a simple numerical suffix (-1, -2, -3, ...) being added
to the instance's 'display_name' and 'hostname' attributes.

We're now in a position to greatly simplify how we do this, so do just
that, removing some comments and updating some documentation that
referenced the removed option in the process.

Change-Id: If5369bcf4a6f7fc36190e153776e60446eb14040

commit_message:
Clean-up tox.ini

* move ostestr execution to [testenv]
* effectively enable `lower-constraints` job execution
* use default configuration for `py36` environment

Change-Id: Id8f914b5a7f4cbc996238c5c4f2b1f352b901e5d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-02 12:47:59.000000000', 'message': "Limit spec-cleaner to older than 1.0.9

spec-cleaner switched from python2 to python 3 only in 1.0.9
(awesome breakage in a patch release). so while we're not
yet ready for python 3 only lets limit to the older version

Change-Id: Ie2282bb8cb0041f206399ac91afaf076dcec2ca3
"}]
commit_message:
Limit spec-cleaner to older than 1.0.9

spec-cleaner switched from python2 to python 3 only in 1.0.9
(awesome breakage in a patch release). so while we're not
yet ready for python 3 only lets limit to the older version

commit_message:
Add sudo package for bootstrap-servers

sudo package is required when we use ubuntu base on centos to deploy.

The following tasks belong to the environment check after
installation of environment-related software packages.
So, move to the post-install module.

    Create kolla user
    Add public key to kolla user authorized keys
    Grant kolla user passwordless sudo
    Ensure node_config_directory directory exists for user kolla
    Ensure node_config_directory directory exists

Change-Id: I86bf5e1df3d6568c4f1ca6f4757f08a3dd22754d
Closes-Bug: #1777571

commit_message:
switch mysql functional tests to PyMySQL

The mysql-python library does not support Python 3, so to be able to
run the functional tests under Python 3 we need a new library. The
oslo.db package uses and supports PyMySQL.

In addition to changing the dependency, change the database connection
string used.

Change-Id: Ide944f8df051bb5e011af1c881387a166d041b7c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Co-Authored-By: Vitalii Solodilov <mcdkr@yandex.ru>

commit_message:
Add SELinux management to containerized undercloud

In instack-undercloud we manage the selinux configuration during the
deployment. This change exposes the configuration as a new tripleo
service for selinux so we can configure it.

Change-Id: I2109bf62e307df92b6bdb57600c58dd61482f46d
Partial-Bug: #1779005

[{'created': '2018-06-18 08:30:16.000000000', 'message': 'Resource tracker: improve resource tracker periodic task

The periodic task would do the following:
1. Reads all of the instances on the node
2. Runs over the list of instances and creates a dictionary
   mapping each instance UUID with the instance object
3. Reads each instacne from the DB to determine its state for
   tracking purposes

This is a large number of wasted cycles when we can save all of
the loops and the unnecesary reads.

This patch proposes the following:
1. When the tracker looks opver th einstance it populates the
   instance uuid dictionary. This save the additioanl loop in
   the migration validations
2. Checks the existing objects to get the instance state. IFF a
   instance is not found then it will read the deleted instance
   from the DB.

Change-Id: Ib7dd4330c05808c9657aa8f1c4acaa3b274c6d77

commit_message:
Resource tracker: improve resource tracker periodic task

The periodic task would do the following:
1. Reads all of the instances on the node
2. Runs over the list of instances and creates a dictionary
   mapping each instance UUID with the instance object
3. Reads each instacne from the DB to determine its state for
   tracking purposes

This is a large number of wasted cycles when we can save all of
the loops and the unnecesary reads.

This patch proposes the following:
1. When the tracker looks opver th einstance it populates the
   instance uuid dictionary. This save the additioanl loop in
   the migration validations
2. Checks the existing objects to get the instance state. IFF a
   instance is not found then it will read the deleted instance
   from the DB.

Change-Id: Ib7dd4330c05808c9657aa8f1c4acaa3b274c6d77

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-28 15:48:34.000000000', 'message': "Fix generate fencing command

On master this command is currently broken:
(undercloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ openstack overcloud generate fencing instackenv.json --output fencing.yaml
Invalid input [name=generate_fencing_parameters, class=DirectWorkflowSpec, missing=['os_auth', 'fence_action']]

The reason for this is that via (A)
I63f3a579af5aa70080f8c9cdd5eb0e8f5b3d17da (Add workflow to generate
fencing parameters) we moved to use a workflow in order to generate
fencing parameters. This workflow took a bunch of inputs which we then
deprecated via two different ways:

(B) os_auth
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570349/ and
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/567896/ we removed some for pxe_ssh but
we did not do it fully in the workbooks

(C) fence_action
Same goes for https://review.openstack.org/#/c/550028/ and
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/556211/ we removed fence_action but
since the workflow still used it as a parameter we broke things

Problem is that the review at (A) got proposed before(B) and (C), but
was merged after them. So it was never amended to account for the
changes introduced in (B) and (C). This change amends things so that
the command works correctly again:
(undercloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ openstack overcloud generate fencing instackenv.json --output fencing.yaml
(undercloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ ls -l fencing.yaml
-rw-rw-r--. 1 stack stack 513 Jun 28 15:46 fencing.yaml

Change-Id: I0262c493c217b64891e7da1bb3853b0d1366faef
Closes-Bug: #1779168
"}]
commit_message:
Fix generate fencing command

On master this command is currently broken:
(undercloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ openstack overcloud generate fencing instackenv.json --output fencing.yaml
Invalid input [name=generate_fencing_parameters, class=DirectWorkflowSpec, missing=['os_auth', 'fence_action']]

The reason for this is that via (A)
I63f3a579af5aa70080f8c9cdd5eb0e8f5b3d17da (Add workflow to generate
fencing parameters) we moved to use a workflow in order to generate
fencing parameters. This workflow took a bunch of inputs which we then
deprecated via two different ways:

(B) os_auth
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570349/ and
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/567896/ we removed some for pxe_ssh but
we did not do it fully in the workbooks

(C) fence_action
Same goes for https://review.openstack.org/#/c/550028/ and
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/556211/ we removed fence_action but
since the workflow still used it as a parameter we broke things

Problem is that the review at (A) got proposed before(B) and (C), but
was merged after them. So it was never amended to account for the
changes introduced in (B) and (C). This change amends things so that
the command works correctly again:
(undercloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ openstack overcloud generate fencing instackenv.json --output fencing.yaml
(undercloud) [stack@undercloud ~]$ ls -l fencing.yaml
-rw-rw-r--. 1 stack stack 513 Jun 28 15:46 fencing.yaml

Change-Id: I0262c493c217b64891e7da1bb3853b0d1366faef
Closes-Bug: #1779168

Switch to using stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1] stestr is
maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.

Let's switch it then.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: I4ba87d9b1db9d1bda50a6c2da194fa79046c387e

commit_message:
Deprecate running Kuryr-Kubernetes with lbaasv2

This commit marks the deprecation of the support of neutron-lbaasv2 in
Kuryr-Kubernetes. It adds a deprecation message, release note and
removes the usage of lbaasv2 in the upstream gates.

From now on, the default option for lbaasv2 will always be octavia.

Change-Id: I528fc7c0462445c880d13268435c993c2e2ff00f
